dishes.brief: Mixed rice with vegetables and egg

dishes.description: A signature Korean rice bowl topped with sautéed vegetables (spinach, bean sprouts, carrots, zucchini), a fried egg, sliced meat, and spicy gochujang sauce. Mixed together before eating for a harmony of flavors and textures.

ingredients.name: Gochujang
ingredients.explanation: Fermented red chili paste — sweet, spicy, and savory. The soul of Korean cooking.

dishes.explanation: A balanced, colorful bowl that's one of Korea's most iconic dishes. The mix-it-yourself format means you control the ratio of rice to toppings.

culturalTerms.explanation: Means 'mixed' — you stir everything together before eating
Means 'rice' — the foundation of the dish

dishes.description: Sweet potato glass noodles stir-fried with colorful vegetables, beef, and seasoned with soy sauce and sesame oil. Often served at celebrations and holidays.

ingredients.name: Sweet potato noodles
ingredients.explanation: Chewy, translucent noodles made from sweet potato starch — glassy and springy.

dishes.explanation: A festive dish traditionally served at Korean celebrations. The glass noodles give it a distinctive chewy texture unlike any Western pasta.

culturalTerms.explanation: Sweet potato starch noodles — the translucent, bouncy noodles used in japchae

dishes.description: A hearty, fiery stew made with aged kimchi, pork belly, tofu, and green onions. Served bubbling hot in a stone pot. The longer the kimchi has fermented, the deeper the flavor.

ingredients.name: Aged kimchi
ingredients.explanation: Fermented napa cabbage — tangy, funky, and spicy. The backbone of Korean cuisine.

ingredients.name: Gochugaru
ingredients.explanation: Korean red pepper flakes — smoky, slightly sweet heat.

dishes.explanation: Korea's ultimate comfort food. Every household has their own recipe, and it's often the first dish Koreans learn to cook.

culturalTerms.explanation: A thick Korean stew, heartier than guk (soup) but thinner than a braise
Extra-aged kimchi (6+ months), preferred for this stew for its deep, complex sourness

dishes.description: Thinly sliced beef marinated in a sweet and savory sauce of soy, pear, garlic, and sesame, then grilled or pan-fried. One of the most internationally recognized Korean dishes.

ingredients.name: Asian pear
ingredients.explanation: Used as a natural meat tenderizer — adds subtle sweetness to the marinade.

dishes.explanation: Literally 'fire meat' — the sweet soy marinade caramelizes beautifully over heat. Often wrapped in lettuce leaves with rice and ssamjang.

culturalTerms.explanation: Fire — refers to the grilling method
Wrapping meat and rice in lettuce leaves — a common way to eat bulgogi

dishes.description: Chewy cylinder-shaped rice cakes simmered in a fiery, sweet gochujang sauce with fish cakes and boiled eggs. Korea's most beloved street food.

ingredients.name: Rice cakes
ingredients.explanation: Chewy cylinders made from rice flour — dense and satisfyingly bouncy.

ingredients.name: Gochujang
ingredients.explanation: Fermented red chili paste — the base of the fiery, sweet sauce.

ingredients.name: Fish cake
ingredients.explanation: Eomuk — pressed fish paste shaped into sheets or tubes, common in Korean street food.

dishes.explanation: The quintessential Korean street food — sweet, spicy, and incredibly addictive. The sauce thickens as it cooks, coating each rice cake in glossy red heat.

culturalTerms.explanation: Korean rice cake — chewy, dense, made from pounded rice flour
Fish cake — processed fish paste shaped into sheets, a tteokbokki staple

dishes.description: Thick slices of unseasoned pork belly grilled at the table on a charcoal or gas grill. Eaten wrapped in lettuce or perilla leaves with garlic, ssamjang, and kimchi.

ingredients.name: Perilla leaves
ingredients.explanation: Kkaennip — aromatic, slightly minty leaf from the sesame family. A classic ssam wrapper.

ingredients.name: Ssamjang
ingredients.explanation: Thick dipping paste — a blend of doenjang (soybean paste) and gochujang. Savory, sweet, spicy.

dishes.explanation: A communal, interactive dining experience — everyone grills and wraps at the table. The name literally means 'three-layer meat' for the visible layers of meat and fat.

culturalTerms.explanation: Three — refers to the three visible layers of meat and fat
Layered meat — pork belly with alternating lean and fat

dishes.description: A bubbling stew of silky uncurdled soft tofu in a spicy broth with vegetables, seafood or pork, and a raw egg cracked in at the table. Served in a sizzling stone pot.

ingredients.name: Gochugaru
ingredients.explanation: Korean red pepper flakes — adds a smoky, fruity heat to the broth.

dishes.explanation: Lighter than kimchi jjigae but equally warming. The raw egg cooks in the bubbling pot at your table — stir it in for a silky, rich broth.

culturalTerms.explanation: Extra-soft, uncurdled tofu — silkier and more delicate than regular tofu
The stone/clay pot it's served in — keeps the stew bubbling at the table

dishes.description: A large, crispy savory pancake loaded with green onions, squid, shrimp, and clams. Served with a soy-vinegar dipping sauce. Perfect with makgeolli (rice wine).
dishes.explanation: A rainy-day tradition in Korea — the sizzle of the pancake on the griddle is said to sound like rain. Koreans often pair it with makgeolli rice wine.

culturalTerms.explanation: Seafood — refers to the mix of squid, shrimp, and shellfish
Green onion pancake — 'pa' means green onion, 'jeon' means pan-fried
